For anyone wondering:
Unlike what minute physics said in the video, the actual sound of hydrogen he used in the video is the Rydberg formula, Lyman and Balmer series sped up by exactly 102%, you can test it by downloading the video going into audacity and manually speeding it up, its that sound.

Hello! May I know how exactly had you interpreted the data in the NIST ASD website (since I'm not very familiar with it)? I tried some things, extracted some data from the "LINES" page in the website...
• I converted the wavelength to frequency and multiplied such that the lowest frequency is 55 Hz (the A note).
• I considered the Relative Intensity column as the column which gives the amplitude of each wave. (is this wrong?)

I also wrote some code to generate a 10-second WAV file of these sum of sine waves! But I had not gotten the same result as you did at 03:53... (by "not same result" I meant that it sounds SOMEWHAT similar to it, but in a different pitch) Is it possible that you guide me where something might've gone wrong? Was the data interpretation from the website incorrect?

I know I'm seven years late.....
From what I've gathered he imported an excel spreadsheet with two columns of numbers. At 3:44 you can see the two variables, Data[[1]] (denoting the first column), and Data[[2]] (the second column). Only the numbers from column 2 are shown, and I found that it is the first wavelength of the Lyman Series (roughly 121.567 nanometers) divided by all the other wavelengths (eg. 121.567nm/91.813nm = 1.32408, the first number). As for the first column, since the video doesn't show it, I haven't worked it out. My best guess is that column 1 is the amplitudes of the wavelengths. Hope this helps!
